page.lettertext:
fol.169r
Belgia 1591
2
8 June
T
o my L Trea
s
Belgia. 1591. June:
May it please yo
r
good L. to be advertised that two daies
after that
e fort of
Delfzile
was yeelded up, w
ch
was don
e 22
of this moneth, as th
e
I writ unto yo
r
L. by two severall l
re
s
or army marched toward
Opslacht,
w
ch
is a sconse that
e
Ennemy held upon a point of land by
Groninghen
Diepe, w
th
in 2
English miles from
Northorne,
where S
r
John Norreis received his
great overthrow. It was 3 daies march from Delfzile, & a place
of good strength, having in it a garrison of 150 souldiers
& 5 great peeces of Artillery first yt was besieged w
th
2000
men, & for half a daie battered w
th
5 cannons: wherupon
being summoned & not yeelding,
e rest of
e army was
caused to approche, w
ch
brought them p
nt
ly to parle. But
better conditions th
e
to de
te w
th
white rodes in theyr hand
would not be graunted. There were found 3 english souldiers
in
e Ennemies
s
vice, w
ch
S
r
Francis Vere
stayd, & caused to
be hanged in
e english quarters. After
e taking of this fort
it was resolved
t
Emmentel
should bee summoned, w
ch
is a
place of like force as
e former, & as wee are
swaded, will
p
nt
ly give over for feare of enforcement to a hard compoisition.
Moreover for that all
e fort
of
e Ennemy in
e Province
of Groninghen w
ch
were not so few as 20 in nomber, are either
tak
e
by us, or forsaken by them selves, wherby
e Towne of
Groning
e
is greatly distressed, & excluded fr
o
all traffike, &
meanes to come by vittailes, unles it be by land by
e
meanes of
Coev
e
orden
, w
ch
is a very strong fort of
e Ennemy,
situate in
t
te of
Overissel,
w
ch
is called
Drent,
southwest
from Groninghen, 7 Duch miles, for
e joining of that place, it
was
is
thought expedient, that
steenwick
a great garrison towne,
upon
e northwest frontiers of overissel should be first taken in,
aswell for
e easier expugnation of Coeveorden, as for sondry other
opportunityes, it being
be
a place
t
doth greatly dammify all
e
countrey therabout. All this was thus concluded yesterday, &
e camp as this day removeth toward
Emmentel. But
e
Councel
of State
ys going toward
Steenwick, both to make provision
for some want
of
e Army, & to accomodate th
e
selves of
some convenient place of resydence neer unto
e Towne./
For w
ch
purpose wee are alredy in o
r
waie so far as
Lewarden
from whence I write yo
r
L. this letter. The Duke of
fol.169v
To my L.
T
re
r
June
28 1591.
Belgia: 1591 June:
Parma
as wee are enformed wanting meanes of cariage
vittailes & many oth
r
necessaries, & also of forces sufficient
to encounter w
th
ours is gon toward
Ruremonde
a strong
towne upon
e Mose in
Gelderland,
w
th
what intention
wee knowe not assuredly, but as many men report to
go for
France.
And yf it be trewe in my conceat
of these actions all
e souldiers of this army are so
very well disposed, &
e contrey so willing to furnishe
[.]
what
ys needfull, as her Ma
ty
shall finde,
t
the
forces of these contreys did never heth
r
too
fourme a better
sommers service.
from Leewarden , June 28. 1591.
